title: Spring 2018 deadline plan to draw line under PPI claims
text:
Banks have reserved £16.6 billion to pay compensation for PPI mis-selling Nick Wright/Getty 2 of 2 PBritain’s five biggest banks have set aside a total of £22.8 billion to cover PPI claims The Canary Wharf financial district is seen at dusk in east London November 7, 2014. Songbird Estates, the majority owner of London’s Canary Wharf, has rejected a 2.2 billion pound ($3.5 billion) takeover proposal from Qatar Investment Authority and Brookfield Property Partners, saying it undervalued the group. REUTERS/Toby Melville (BRITAIN - Tags: BUSINESS REAL ESTATE) Toby Melville/Reuters Katherine Griffiths Banking Editor Last updated at 9:49AM, October 2 2015 
Bank customers will have until spring 2018 to complain about payment protection insurance under a proposed deadline which will bring an end to Britain’s largest mis-selling scandal. 
The deadline has been pushed for by banks, which have set aside £27 billion to cover PPI complaints. Of that, some £20 billion has been paid to ten million customers. 
Shares in Lloyds, the largest PPI offender which has so far incurred £13.4 billion in costs over PPI, rose 2.5 per cent to 77p in early trading.
